active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the scenarios where time-based SQLi would be the attacker's preferred blind technique over boolean-based SQLi (e.g., high-traffic sites with suppressed errors). Provide real-world examples from breaches like the 2011 Sony Pictures hack and evaluate trade-offs in stealth vs. speed.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education. Generate 50 high-quality flashcards on 'Time-Based SQL Injection' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Common Web Application Vulnerabilities > 001_Injection Vulnerabilities > SQL Injection > Time-Based SQL Injection). Strictly follow the provided schema: multiple-choice with 4 options (1 correct), detailed back with explanation, hints, Bloom level. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [paste full list above]. Tag each card with matching Bloom level (balance: 20% Remember/Understand, 30% Apply/Analyze, 30% Evaluate, 20% Create). - Scaffolding Layers: [paste full layers]. Distribute 12-13 cards per layer. - Active Learning: Weave in discussion/peer/problems (e.g., 'As in peer-teach: ...'). - Research/Completeness: OWASP A03:2021, CWE-89, PortSwigger labs, prevention (prepared stmts), detection (time anomalies), examples (SLEEP(5), WAITFOR). - Prior Knowledge: Link to basic SQLi. - Concept Map: Reference branches. Distractors: Follow protocol exactly (common misconceptions like confusing with boolean SQLi). Output ONLY a JSON array: [{'front': {'question': '...', 'options': ['A:...','B:...']}, 'back': {'correct_answer': 'A:...', 'explanation': '...', 'hints': [...], 'bloom_level': 'APPLY'}} , ... ]. No extra text.
